0.24.text:
SECRETARY KERRY: Well, today we present the
department’s International Religious Freedom

5.46.text:
Report for 2014. And I particularly want to
thank David Saperstein and his entire team

13.02.text:
for producing a report that reflects a vast
amount of objective research and that will

21.11.text:
provide a uniquely valuable resource for anybody
who cares about religious freedom in all of

27.93.text:
its aspects. And I am very grateful for David’s
willingness to come on board. He has provided

35.19.text:
important new energy and focus on this, is
building a terrific team, and I think you’re

41.39.text:
going to hear more and more from the Department
with respect to our fight to protect people’s

49.03.text:
right to exercise religious freedom. The message
at the heart of this report is that countries

56.64.text:
benefit when their citizens fully enjoy the
rights to which they are entitled. And this

63.31.text:
is not a hopeful theory; this is a proven
reality. No nation can fulfill its potential

69.60.text:
if its people are denied the right to practice,
to hold, to modify, to openly profess their

77.62.text:
innermost beliefs. I should emphasize that
the concept of religious freedom extends way

85.50.text:
beyond mere tolerance. It is a concept grounded
in respect for the rights and beliefs of others.

94.64.text:
It is deeply connected to our DNA as Americans
– to everything that we are and everything

100.34.text:
that we came from. It’s a concept that is
based on respect, and respect, in turn, demands

110.09.text:
legal equality. It demands that the practitioners
of one faith understand that they have no

116.69.text:
right to coerce others into submission, conversion,
or silence, or to literally take their lives

125.81.text:
because of their beliefs. The purpose of this
annual report is to highlight the importance

131.57.text:
of religious freedom not by lecturing but
through advocacy and through persuasion. Our

139.72.text:
primary goal is to help governments everywhere
recognize that their societies will do better

146.11.text:
with religious liberty than without it. The
world has learned through very hard experience

153.51.text:
that religious pluralism encourages and enables
contributions from all; while religious discrimination

160.34.text:
is often the source of conflicts that endanger
all. By issuing this report, we hope to give

166.96.text:
governments an added incentive to honor the
rights and the dignity of their citizens;

173.64.text:
but the report also has the benefit of equipping
interested observers with an arsenal of facts.

181.17.text:
And one of the more consequential facts of
our era has been the convergence – really,

188.73.text:
the development of a sort of new phenomenon
of non-state actors who, unlike the last century

198.63.text:
and the violence that we saw and persecution
that we saw that emanated from states, are

203.43.text:
now the principal persecutors and preventers
of religious tolerance and practice. Most

211.98.text:
prominent, and most harmful, obviously, has
been the rise of international terrorist groups

217.34.text:
such as Daesh, al-Qaida, al-Shabaab, Boko
Haram. And all have been guilty of vicious

225.78.text:
acts of unprovoked violence. Under their control,
captives have been given a choice between

233.32.text:
conversion or slavery or death. Children have
been among the victims, and also among those

241.43.text:
forced to witness or participate in executions
– sometimes even of their own family members.

249.65.text:
Entire populations of religious minority groups
have been targeted for killing. Terrified

255.33.text:
young girls have been separated out by religion
and sold into slavery. The repugnance of these

262.16.text:
acts is only multiplied when the perpetrators
seek to justify themselves by pointing a finger

268.53.text:
at God and claiming somehow that God licensed
these acts. We are, and we will continue,

277.19.text:
to oppose these groups with far more than
words of condemnation that are contained in

282.87.text:
this report. We will also continue to help
the survivors. In the Middle East, and in

289.26.text:
Africa, we are assisting local partners in
responding to the needs – both physical

294.57.text:
and psychological – of women and girls who
have escaped or been released after having

300.83.text:
been held captive by terrorist groups. Each
victim, each nightmare, each wound is another

308.81.text:
reason to urgently address the root causes
of violent extremism. And before closing,

315.40.text:
I just want to make three general points.
First, as much as we oppose the actions of

322.58.text:
terrorists, we do not agree with governments
that use those crimes as a pretext for prohibiting

329.30.text:
religious activities that are in fact nonviolent
and legitimate. Those who misuse the terms

336.87.text:
“terrorist” and “extremist” are not
fooling anybody, and trying to dictate an

341.93.text:
artificial conformity of religious expression
is not a prescription for harmony. It is a

348.14.text:
prescription for frustration, anger, and rebellion.
And we have learned time and again that if

354.33.text:
citizens are denied the rights to practice
and express their beliefs peacefully, they

359.59.text:
are far more likely to explore other and more
often than not dangerous alternatives.

367.66.text:
Second, the right to religious freedom is
not contingent on having a large number of

374.77.text:
followers. Religious minorities – including
those who profess no faith – should have

381.96.text:
the same rights as religious majorities, and
that is a fundamental belief. Sadly, the pages

389.37.text:
of this report that is being released today
are filled with accounts of minorities being

394.86.text:
denied rights in countries like Burma, Iran,
Pakistan, Russia, Saudi Arabia, many others.

404.85.text:
And finally, I want to emphasize the importance
and urgency of the work that is being carried

409.87.text:
out by Ambassador Saperstein and his office,
including the addition of a new special advisor

415.75.text:
on religious minorities. Among their initiatives
is a groundbreaking effort to build a coalition

422.83.text:
of likeminded nations to uphold the international
standard of religious freedom for all.

430.04.text:
In that connection, I urge the release of
men and women detained or imprisoned anywhere

435.39.text:
in the world for the peaceful expression and
practice of their religious beliefs. This

441.45.text:
includes Mr. Zhang Kai, a Chinese Christian
human rights lawyer who was detained in late

447.04.text:
August just prior to a scheduled meeting with
Ambassador Saperstein, and whose present whereabouts

453.79.text:
are unknown.
In closing, I note that religious bigotry

460.02.text:
is present to a degree in every continent
and every country, and sadly, even including

465.90.text:
our own. It may be expressed through anti-Semitism
or prejudice against Muslims; through the

474.38.text:
persecution of Christians, Hindus, Buddhists,
Sikhs, and others; or it may come in the guise

480.87.text:
of attacks against religion itself, as we
saw so tragically in Oregon at the beginning

487.60.text:
of this month.
In response, we all have a responsibility

493.38.text:
to affirm our faith in the principles of religious
freedom that the world community has endorsed

498.99.text:
so many times and that have helped to uplift
America and define our country since the 17th

506.77.text:
century, when Roger Williams issued his call
for soul liberty, and when, some years later,

514.07.text:
Seneca chief Red Jacket told a missionary
delegation from Boston, “Brother, we do

520.13.text:
not wish to destroy your religion. We only
want to enjoy our own.” That’s the fundamental

527.22.text:
principle of tolerance that guides us, and
it is a value worth fighting for.

532.99.text:
With that, I am pleased to yield the floor
to Ambassador David Saperstein, who will give

536.71.text:
you a little more detail about the report.
Thank you all.

542.77.text:
AMBASSADOR SAPERSTEIN: I want to thank the
Secretary, not just for his remarks; he made

567.43.text:
a number of commitments of support for this
work when I came on, and he has more than

573.13.text:
fulfilled those commitments.
The Annual International Religious Freedom

579.34.text:
Report provides an important opportunity for
the United States to highlight an issue that

585.06.text:
continues to be a foreign policy priority
for the Administration, documenting how, where,

590.51.text:
and when the universal right of freedom of
religion or belief was violated or protected

597.60.text:
in every corner of the world.
Through the immense effort of countless State

601.44.text:
Department officials, particularly our knowledgeable
and tireless staff of the International Religious

607.18.text:
Freedom Office and the Bureau of Democracy,
Human Rights, and Labor in Washington, as

612.05.text:
well as dedicated staff in each one of our
embassies across the globe, the 2014 report

620.50.text:
maintains the high standards of objectivity
and accuracy for which we strive.

624.91.text:
A little over a year ago, I stood at a podium
next to Secretary Kerry here in this room

631.71.text:
when he announced my nomination for the position
of Ambassador-at-Large, and during my 10-month

636.67.text:
tenure I have been gratified by the support
from both the Secretary and the President

641.49.text:
in implementing so many of the priorities
I identified in my confirmation hearing and

647.02.text:
my swearing-in speech. We have since increased
the number of staff in my office, allowing

652.07.text:
us to expand our country monitoring work and
better address a variety of issues – from

659.15.text:
the importance of religious freedom and countering
violent extremism to the terrible global impact

666.47.text:
of blasphemy laws. Simultaneously, we have
expanded foreign assistance programs that

672.26.text:
strengthen religious freedom.
I’m also deeply appreciative of President

676.62.text:
Obama’s and Secretary Kerry’s support
for the appointment of Knox Thames as special

683.01.text:
advisor for religious minorities in the Near
East and South Central Asia; I’m delighted

688.78.text:
that he’s able to be with us today. Knox
will build upon our already intense efforts

693.63.text:
on behalf of these minorities over the past
year, including our work to protect Yezidis

699.41.text:
in those early days and weeks on Mount Sinjar
in Iraq and the Assyrian Christian communities

704.49.text:
of the Khabur River area of Syria. Knox will
help guide the U.S. Government-wide efforts

709.89.text:
to promote conditions in these countries that
will allow members of displaced minority communities

716.14.text:
to be able to return home.
Since January, I’ve also worked to build

720.84.text:
deeper partnerships with foreign governments
to advance religious freedom as these global

726.19.text:
challenges require a global response. Thanks
to the leadership of my Canadian counterpart,

732.90.text:
Ambassador Andrew Bennett, we have forged
an intergovernmental contact group bringing

738.15.text:
together likeminded nations to devise common
strategies to promote and protect religious

743.69.text:
freedom for all.
Now, during my tenure I’ve noticed certain

746.69.text:
enduring truths. In many countries, religious
freedoms flourish; people are free to choose

753.62.text:
their faith, change their faith, speak about
their faith to others, teach their faith to

758.35.text:
their children, dissent from religion, build
places of worship, worship alone or in fellowship

763.10.text:
with others. In such societies, denominations
and faith groups organize as their leaders

768.32.text:
and members see fit. Interfaith cooperation
flourishes, religious communities contribute

774.04.text:
significantly to the social welfare and serve
as a moral compass to their nations.

779.77.text:
Yet in far too many countries people face
daunting, alarming, growing challenges on

784.72.text:
account of their beliefs. In countries where
once proud traditions of multi-faith cooperation,

790.79.text:
positive coexistence was the norm, we have
witnessed growing numbers of religious minorities

797.03.text:
being driven out of their historic homelands.
And in too many countries, prisoners of conscience

802.27.text:
suffer cruel punishment for their religious
beliefs and practices. This report gives a

807.50.text:
voice to all those around the world who are
seeking to peacefully live their lives in

812.51.text:
accordance with their conscience or religious
beliefs.

815.10.text:
In the pages of this report, we strive to
put a human face on this incredibly important

821.01.text:
human right that touches so many people across
the globe and remains central to the identity

827.47.text:
of the American people.
A number of trend lines stood out in this

831.60.text:
year’s report. The first one, the Secretary
has already mentioned, is the single greatest

836.96.text:
challenge to religious freedom worldwide,
or certainly the single greatest emerging

843.70.text:
challenge, and that is the abhorrent acts
of terror committed by those who falsely claim

848.65.text:
the mantle of religion to justify their wanton
destruction.

851.81.text:
In both Iraq and Syria, Daesh has sought to
eliminate anyone daring to deviate from its

857.44.text:
own violent and destructive interpretation
of Islam. Targets include non-Muslims, Shia,

864.05.text:
Sunnis alike. It has displaced individuals
from their homes based on their religions

868.91.text:
or ethnicity. Similarly, Boko Haram has killed
thousands in both indiscriminate violence

874.57.text:
and deliberate attacks on Christians and Muslims
who oppose its radical ideology. It has subjected

881.98.text:
the peoples of Nigeria, Cameroon, Chad, Niger,
to unspeakable acts of terror, sexual violence,

888.83.text:
abductions, and fatal attacks on places of
worship.

892.84.text:
Secondly, the impact of blasphemy laws and
apostasy laws in countries including Pakistan,

899.86.text:
Saudi Arabia, Egypt, Sudan, and in a number
of others – as well as laws that purport

904.81.text:
to protect religious sentiments from offense.
The United States uniformly opposes such laws

911.80.text:
which are used to oppress those whose religious
beliefs happen to offend the majority. Such

917.06.text:
laws are inconsistent with international human
rights and fundamental freedoms, and we will

921.52.text:
continue to call for their universal repeal.
The existence of such laws has been used in

927.36.text:
some countries as pretext to justify violence
in the name of religion to create an atmosphere

933.39.text:
of impunity for those resorting to violence
and/or leads to false claims of blasphemy.

940.79.text:
Third, repressive governments routinely subject
their citizens to violence, detention, discrimination,

947.60.text:
undue surveillance, for simply exercising
their faith or identifying with a religious

953.27.text:
community. We see this dramatized by the plight
of countless numbers of prisoners of conscience.

959.77.text:
We remain deeply committed to seeing such
individuals freed everywhere in the world.

966.28.text:
In my travels to Vietnam, I saw firsthand
how religious groups are forced to undergo

971.16.text:
onerous and arbitrary registration process
to legally operate. As Vietnam considers amending

978.30.text:
its religion laws, we stand with the country’s
religious communities in calling for the easing

984.19.text:
of such restrictions. And in Burma, Ambassador
Bennett of Canada and I spoke out forcefully

990.02.text:
together against a series of discriminatory
laws banning interfaith marriage and restricting

995.90.text:
conversion.
Many governments have used the guise of confronting

999.34.text:
terrorism or extremism to broadly repress
religious groups for nonviolent religious

1004.90.text:
activities, or by imposing broad restrictions
on religious life. Russia continues to use

1011.35.text:
vaguely formulated anti-extremism laws to
justify arrests, raids on homes and places

1017.18.text:
of worship, and the confiscation or banning
of religious literature. Tajikistan bans people

1022.57.text:
under age of 18 from participating in any
public religious activities, supposedly on

1029.53.text:
the ground that exposure to religion will
lead youths to violence. Chinese officials

1034.45.text:
have increased controls on Uighur Muslims’
peaceful religious expression and practice,

1040.34.text:
including instances of banning beards and
headscarves.

1043.34.text:
And a word about China: During my visit in
August, I found that despite widespread, continuing

1049.81.text:
government abuses and restriction, many places
of worship were nonetheless full and flourishing.

1056.57.text:
In areas of the country where the government’s
hand was lighter, faith-based social service

1060.61.text:
and welfare agencies operating homeless shelters,
orphanages, soup kitchens, made highly positive

1066.36.text:
contributions to the wellbeing of their society.
We’ve urged the Chinese Government to use

1072.58.text:
that as a model of what can work nationwide.
But far more often restrictive policies still

1079.10.text:
stifled religious life, preventing Chinese
people from experiencing such benefits. This

1085.00.text:
reality has only been exacerbated by the growing
crackdown on human rights lawyers in China,

1090.66.text:
including those seeking to work within China’s
legal system to enhance religious freedom.

1096.92.text:
And this does include Zhang Kai, a peaceful,
respected, Christian human rights lawyer who

1102.59.text:
was detained just prior to a meeting with
me and whose whereabouts remain unknown.

1108.21.text:
A fourth trend is the role of societal violence
and discrimination, that which emanates not

1115.99.text:
from the government itself but from other
societal groups. And the question is: What

1121.16.text:
does the government do to try and ameliorate
the conditions that lead to such violence,

1126.30.text:
and what does it do to protect harassed minority
communities? In Europe, many governments are

1132.62.text:
struggling to cope with the aftermath of terror
attacks such as those in France, Belgium and

1137.24.text:
Denmark, along with increased anti-Semitism
and anti-Muslim actions and sentiments. As

1144.16.text:
hundreds of thousands of Syrians, Afghans,
Iraqis and others have fled into Europe in

1149.53.text:
recent weeks, we urge governments to uphold
their obligations for humane treatment of

1155.01.text:
refugees and ensuring that individuals do
not face harassment or discrimination on account

1160.82.text:
of their Muslim faith.
Now, despite these many challenges detailed

1165.22.text:
in our report, we also see governments and
individuals working to improve their communities

1170.51.text:
and societies. Following the terror attacks
in Copenhagen in February, thousands of people

1176.12.text:
of different faiths formed in Denmark a human
ring outside the synagogue where the murder

1181.12.text:
occurred. In September of 2014, Kyrgyzstan’s
constitutional court ruled part of the country’s

1188.22.text:
problematic religion law unconstitutional,
a decision we hope will ease registration

1192.64.text:
requirements for minority religious groups
and enable members to engage in peaceful religious

1198.45.text:
activities more freely.
After years of growing religious tensions

1202.78.text:
and violence in Sri Lanka generated by hardline
ethnic Buddhist groups, a new government has

1208.53.text:
taken office and staked out a much more tolerant
view of religious diversity. Since that time,

1214.00.text:
some of these tensions have noticeably eased.
In closing, while the challenges are daunting,

1219.67.text:
we are deeply inspired by the work of countless
religious communities, civil society organizations,

1225.32.text:
and individuals around the world working alongside
us to ensure that their governments live up

1231.28.text:
to their international commitments to protect
freedom of religious and belief. We dedicate

1236.49.text:
our work to their struggle and continue to
fight for a world in which every individual

1241.38.text:
is free to live out the core of his or her
conscience.

1244.73.text: I’m now happy to answer any questions.

1247.54.text: MR TONER: Any takers? Go ahead, David.

1250.43.text:
QUESTION: You’ve sketched out a number of
things that are going badly and a few things

1254.09.text:
that are going well. Is it possible to look
at a global trend? Are things better than

1260.94.text: they were when you took office or worse, globally?

1265.26.text:
AMBASSADOR SAPERSTEIN: If you look at the
Pew reports that I believe are a year behind

1272.45.text:
our reports, over the last several years there’s
been a steady increase in the percentage of

1278.11.text:
people who live in countries that are – that
have serious restrictions on religious freedom.

1287.22.text:
And of course, as both the Secretary and I
pointed out, the escalation of the violence

1294.24.text:
perpetrated by non-state actors, often in
the name of their interpretation of religion,

1301.95.text:
is a new phenomenon that has really escalated
in the last 18 months. So on that level, there

1311.01.text:
are trends that are deeply troubling. At the
same time, if you look and for – just take

1318.71.text:
one example in Europe, and you look at the
acts of anti-Semitism and anti-Muslim activity

1324.32.text:
that took place, across Europe leaders of
the different countries and civil society

1329.36.text:
leaders and religious leaders have all spoken
out condemning these acts, taking steps to

1334.66.text:
help prevent these acts, standing in protection
of minority communities with many governments

1340.12.text:
deploying either police or militia to protect
endangered minority communities. And we’ve

1347.95.text:
seen enormous expansion of interfaith efforts
on almost every continent to try and address

1354.01.text:
the challenges. So it’s hard to give you
the sum between the dangerous and the encouraging

1363.33.text:
parts of it. This report doesn’t make those
kinds of judgment. It just states in facts

1368.41.text: what is happening in each and every country.

1372.94.text:
QUESTION: Just to follow up the China situation,
have the Chinese Government responded in any

1378.02.text:
way to your questions about the detention
of this Zhang Kai, I think his name is? And

1384.02.text:
also, what are the circumstances of the people
who were detained around the same time? And

1388.03.text:
sorry – finally, how do you explain that
balance or that kind of mixed message between

1393.42.text:
religious – a certain amount of religious
freedom or expression, but on the other hand

1396.77.text:
increasing restrictions, especially when you
were actually there?

1400.76.text:
AMBASSADOR SAPERSTEIN: So let me clarify what
the situation was. At the very end of our

1406.54.text:
time in mainland China, these detentions took
place. One was of somebody – someone with

1415.81.text:
a human rights legal background who had met
with us to give the analysis that that person

1422.47.text:
brought to bear on the subject, who was detained
the next day in house detention.

1429.72.text:
About 10 of the people from the community
of Wenzhou – now that, I’m sure, many

1435.58.text:
of you have read about. That’s a community
where there’s been an escalation of efforts

1441.32.text:
to take down crosses from a few hundred churches,
to dismantle some churches in Wenzhou. And

1453.20.text:
we wanted to meet with people there. We were
denied permission to actually travel there,

1458.69.text:
but we were allowed to go to the capital of
that province. And that group of people – including

1465.69.text:
three human rights lawyers, four pastors from
the area, three or four other activists, a

1472.29.text:
group of about 10 people – were all detained.
Several of them have been released. Several

1478.34.text:
of them still face the possibility of charges.
And with Zhang Kai, who really is one of the

1486.84.text:
most respected human rights lawyers in China,
someone who has argued over and over again

1492.64.text:
that they have to work within the legal system
of China in order to win these battles and

1497.70.text:
has proved very skilled at doing that, representing
a range of religious groups, he and I believe

1504.93.text:
one or two or the others are still in locations
where we’re not sure where they are. This

1510.56.text:
is not an uncommon occurrence. And on – our
human rights bureau has reached out in all

1516.27.text:
their encounters. We’re trying to talk about
these problems in a structural level. We have

1520.68.text:
continued to ask questions. We will continue
on this. And we hope that we will get answers.

1528.20.text:
Just on one foot – again, the report doesn’t
make the judgments about why these disparity

1535.88.text:
of experiences, these encouraging signs and
these deeply discouraging signs, live side

1541.47.text:
by side in the same country. It just sets
out the facts and allows you folks to provide

1550.48.text:
QUESTION: Thanks for doing this, Mr. Ambassador.
The report talks about a wave of anti-Israel

1556.96.text:
sentiment in Europe in 2014 that crossed the
line into anti-Semitism. And I’m wondering

1562.33.text:
if you could explain to us how you defined
where that line was. What constituted anti-Israel

1570.90.text:
AMBASSADOR SAPERSTEIN: We actually have a
very brief paper on that. If you’d like,

1575.39.text:
we can provide that to you. But just very
quickly here, criticism of the public policy

1584.35.text:
of any nation – Israel, the United States,
China, a European nation, African nation,

1591.51.text:
Asian nation – no matter what the nation
is, that’s appropriate. That’s part of

1597.25.text:
the free marketplace of ideas and discourse.
Where it has often crossed the line is when

1604.86.text:
groups try to argue that Israel is an inherently
illegal state and doesn’t have a right to

1613.00.text:
exist as a Jewish state here and takes actions
to de-legitimize those fundamental rights.

1622.35.text:
It comes – it’s right on the cusp of that
line when it holds one country to different

1627.07.text:
standards than it would hold any other country.
Normally we think of that as the denial of

1633.34.text:
rights to a person that are given to other
similarly situated people, or the imposition

1639.03.text:
of obligations on a person not applied to
other people. We normally think of that as

1646.31.text:
racism. And this, in the minds of many, feels
that when it steps over that line, that it

1655.03.text:
constitutes anti-Semitic activity and not
just anti-legitimate discourse about Israel’s

1662.90.text: MR TONER: In the back. Michele.

1666.53.text:
QUESTION: Hi, how are you? When you look at
what ISIS is doing in the Middle East, would

1670.04.text:
you describe that as a war on Christians?
What more could the U.S. do to protect communities

1675.71.text:
like that or to help resettle people here?
And then finally, what would you tell Russia

1683.21.text:
about Bashar al-Assad’s record on protecting
minorities in that country?

1690.53.text:
AMBASSADOR SAPERSTEIN: That’s a broad range
of issues. Let me try to do this quickly,

1694.52.text:
working backwards. The – Assad’s record
is absolutely clear. We have made that clear

1703.35.text:
to the world. I think there’s overwhelming
consensus in the global community about the

1709.56.text:
horrific abuses of human rights that the Assad
regime has been engaged in. And so Russia’s

1720.56.text:
intervention doesn’t change what our message
on that has been.

1725.56.text:
In terms of bringing people here, the President
has announced an expansion in the number of

1732.07.text:
refugees that we will be taking in. It is
presumed a number of those will include – of

1737.10.text:
the expansion will include people from that
– will include people from that region.

1744.40.text:
We have worked vigorously on the issue of
protecting the minority communities. ISIL

1750.55.text:
is certainly targeting the Christian community,
but is also targeting the Mandaeans, the Shabak,

1757.79.text:
certainly the Yezidis that explicitly said
it wanted to wipe out here. So it is trying

1763.67.text:
to decimate and eviscerate the presence of
those very communities here. And we know that

1773.27.text:
if there’s going to be a possibility to
bring them home, we know what the ingredients

1777.60.text:
are going to be. I’ve spoken on this publicly
to a number of the major Christian groups

1783.90.text:
who are concerned about this, but also the
groups that are concerned about the – in

1788.58.text:
meetings with the Yezidi, the Shia Muslim
groups from the area who are affected by this

1796.40.text:
as well.
That is, we need to sustain them where they

1800.27.text:
are in place at a condition that they’re
going to be willing to stay – mostly in

1807.21.text:
Kurdistan – until ISIL’s presence is removed.
And we clearly need to remove ISIL’s presence

1815.55.text:
for them to return home. That means there
have to be schools for their kids, there has

1819.42.text:
to be better health care, there have to be
job opportunities for their kids who are graduating

1825.62.text:
school, et cetera. And the United States is
the lead factor in providing that kind of

1831.66.text:
humanitarian aid.
Secondly, there needs to be a security system

1836.77.text:
when they return home in which they can trust,
because a lot of that trust was breached when

1843.23.text:
ISIL came in. And they need their own – the
right to have their own effective defense

1848.85.text:
forces that have to be integrated with the
Iraqi and Peshmerga forces.

1853.13.text:
Third, there has to be a restorative justice,
a transitional justice system. People go back

1858.76.text:
to their communities; some of their former
neighbors have taken over their businesses,

1863.89.text:
their homes. There has to be a system that
will fairly adjudicate that and hold people

1867.98.text:
responsible who assisted ISIL.
Fourth, at a macro level in Iraq, there has

1875.08.text:
to be a change in the governance structures
that allow those minority groups to have a

1879.62.text:
real role in shaping the future of the country.
Prime Minister Abadi has made clear that that

1887.28.text:
is his intent. We see some of that represented
in appointments that he’s made, and the

1892.36.text:
United States is working with the Iraqi Government
on that day in and day out.

1896.96.text:
And finally, there has to be an internationally
engaged plan on the economic rebuilding so

1902.55.text:
that people will have a sense of hope for
the future. We know what those ingredients

1906.49.text:
are. The United States, often together with
the UN or other nations, are working on planning

1911.73.text:
in this. And that’s very important because
if it were – we waited until ISIL was pushed

1917.91.text:
out, it would leave a vacuum that chaos would
potentially descend.

1922.80.text:
And so we know what needs to be done. We’re
working on those things – and pushing very

1927.18.text:
hard – that will benefit the Christian community.
I mean, think about it. There’s been a Christian

1931.95.text:
community there for 1600 years. Across the
Nineveh plain, church bells have pealed for

1937.59.text:
1600 years. Today they are silent. And we
are not going to rest until people have a

1945.31.text:
right to live out their religious lives back
in their home communities in accordance with

1950.23.text: MR TONER: A couple more questions.

1952.03.text:
QUESTION: Thank you. On North Korea and on
religious freedom and human rights in North

1957.77.text:
Korea, in North Korea they detained many of
the religions and the pastors for past years,

1965.89.text:
then they are still in prisons. So how – would
you please tell us: How many U.S. citizens

1975.41.text:
still in the North Korean prisons? Can you
guess how many U.S. citizen pastors or religions

1984.29.text:
AMBASSADOR SAPERSTEIN: First, as you know,
Korea remains a country of particular concern

1994.20.text:
for us. It is one of the worst violators of
human rights in the entire world. We have

2002.03.text:
talked about that over and over again. The
countries of particular concern who were this

2009.92.text:
past year continue this year. I think everyone
knows that list – Burma, China, Eritrea,

2015.01.text:
Iran, North Korea, Saudi Arabia, Sudan, Turkmenistan,
Uzbekistan.

2021.02.text:
Secondly, we continue – we don’t have
direct relations, so we continue through international

2026.53.text:
partners and by mobilizing these international
coalitions to put continuing pressure for

2033.31.text:
North Korea to ease its restrictions on religious
freedom and to let every one of those prisoners

2038.73.text:
of conscience – and there are far, far too
many, and they often face brutal conditions

2044.93.text:
in the prisons – to go.
And finally, the United States Government

2050.23.text:
is always working, day in and day out, to
ensure that its citizens who are imprisoned

2056.22.text:
unjustly without due process and for the exercise
of fundamental internationally protected rights

2064.66.text:
are allowed to go free, and/or encounter a
judicial system that does provide due process

2074.27.text:
and fairness. We do that as best we can through
the international contacts with North Korea

2082.53.text:
going on every day on an ongoing basis.
The question of how many, I actually don’t

2089.08.text:
know the answer to. The specific cases we
can’t comment on. American privacy laws

2094.25.text:
protect us from – protect them from allowing
us to talk about their situation, and they’re

2101.91.text:
not in a position to give us authority and
permission to do that. So we can’t comment

2110.82.text:
QUESTION: In your outreach to countries to
address religious freedom concerns, do you

2115.15.text:
ever get pushback from governments who may
view the idea of religious freedom as a Western

2121.87.text:
AMBASSADOR SAPERSTEIN: We do, and it has been
somewhat of a growing phenomenon. Here – we

2130.92.text:
therefore make it clear over and over again
we are not trying to impose the standards

2136.25.text:
of Western countries, of countries of any
particular majorities – religious majorities

2143.00.text:
– here, or American, European standards
on any of these countries. Almost all of these

2150.27.text:
countries we’re dealing with are signatories
to the Universal Declaration of Human Rights,

2155.03.text:
the International Covenant on Civil and Political
Rights – Article 18 is quite clear about

2160.14.text:
a robust application of religious freedom.
We regard these as internationally protected

2165.62.text:
rights, and it is within that guise that we
deal with it.

2169.58.text:
Let me just point out, however, that we respect
the varied traditions of people up to the

2175.05.text:
point it violates those international norms.
We try to engage with them on their terms

2180.91.text:
to find ways to address what concerns they
might have about defamation of religion, about

2186.11.text:
attacks on religion, about the questions of
what religiously would be – would constitute

2191.83.text:
blasphemy by finding non-legal ways to deal
with that. The passage of UN Resolution 1618

2197.41.text:
is a prime example of that. It enjoyed the
support of the OIC in passing it. It looks

2204.62.text:
at non-penal ways to address some of these
questions.

2209.88.text:
And we have set up a very effective training
program drawing on the Justice Department,

2214.86.text:
the Homeland Security Department, and the
State Department. Working with other experts

2220.50.text:
around the world, we’re out in other countries
doing training programs about this, and the

2226.93.text:
countries – it’s been a handful of countries
we’ve done a test run on, and now we’re

2230.91.text:
going to be expanding this in a much more
global reach. It’s one of the things that

2235.47.text:
I’m focused on doing. And that’s where
we engage people where they are and try and

2241.02.text:
bring them in ways to address their concerns
within international legal norms.

2246.12.text:
MR TONER: Really, last few questions. In the
back there and then Nicole.

2252.00.text:
QUESTION: Thank you, Ambassador, for your
time. The Syria Catholic patriarch last week

2255.33.text:
said that Christians in the Middle East feel
like the West has abandoned them. How do you

2259.33.text:
respond, and how can this report help in their
crisis right now?

2265.33.text:
AMBASSADOR SAPERSTEIN: Sometimes there are
competing truths – two things that are absolutely

2270.60.text:
true here. There is a robust effort of the
developed world – of the democratic world,

2277.98.text:
excuse me – to help protect the Christian
communities. They are – all of the efforts

2285.20.text:
that we’re doing in terms of supporting
the humanitarian needs of Syrian refugees,

2289.96.text:
of Iraqi refugees; of working with the Government
of Iraq in the lines – along the lines that

2295.35.text:
I was talking about in the international community
manifest that. Day in and day out there isn’t

2301.54.text:
a single day that we are not doing more and
more. The – bringing Knox Thames, such a

2308.76.text:
respected advocate of religious freedom – for
those of you who don’t know Knox, he had

2312.68.text:
been the director of policy and research at
the U.S. Commission on International Religious

2318.34.text:
Freedom, widely respected in the field – who
hit the ground running when he came on just

2323.98.text:
within the last couple of weeks, he’s going
to be working side by side with me and with

2330.12.text:
our international counterparts and with every
arm of our government that is doing programs,

2336.23.text:
working on defense training and work with
countries in the area here (inaudible) the

2341.97.text:
intelligence communities, all of the human
rights work that we’re doing here, to help

2347.16.text:
really strengthen the work on behalf of these
minorities.

2350.64.text:
That’s one reality. I mean, I could talk
for hours about what is being done, the programmatic

2355.79.text:
work that’s being done – the relief and
humanitarian work, et cetera. They’re in

2362.50.text:
the middle of a horrific war situation. Every
day their lives could be imperiled. There’s

2370.13.text:
no magic button that can fix this. It is – as
the President has said, it is going to be

2376.17.text:
long, steady progress here until we can reach
the kind of goals that we want. If you’re

2383.23.text:
living there and you fear for the well being
of your family every day, certainly you’re

2386.98.text:
going to feel like the world isn’t doing
enough about it. It’s a paradox. We recognize

2393.06.text:
that reality. We do everything we can to ameliorate
that, to offer greater protection and to meet

2399.91.text:
the needs of these communities, and we won’t
cease doing so until they really are able

2405.50.text:
to live in freedom in accordance with their
conscience.

2407.91.text:
MR TONER: Nicole, last question (inaudible)
sorry.

2411.00.text:
QUESTION: Does the State Department consider
efforts by Western countries to ban the Muslim

2416.11.text:
headdress or the Muslim covering for women
as a repression of religious freedom?

2421.72.text:
And second, very quick, if you can. Iran,
Saudi Arabia – which one is more respectful

2432.18.text:
AMBASSADOR SAPERSTEIN: Both of them, as you
heard, are on the list of the countries of

2437.47.text:
particular concern here and continue to be
on that list, Nicole. So we don’t make judgments

2446.49.text:
about which are better and worse. Both of
those countries have structural, systematic,

2452.66.text:
egregious violations. Minority in Saudi Arabia
– no one other than Muslim community can

2458.97.text:
worship openly, can partake in their religious
life openly. Even when they do it privately,

2466.01.text:
often they’re harassed and interfered with.
These are very serious challenges and problems.

2473.07.text:
In Iran, we have very serious problems as
well. Again, the Shia Muslim community – interpretation

2482.47.text:
of Islam dominates the legal structure, the
culture of the country. Other Muslims find

2487.48.text:
themselves – Mahdi Muslims find themselves
in trouble; in the Baha’i community, systematically

2494.86.text:
oppressed. Almost every minority group faces
restrictions and are discriminated against

2501.26.text:
in one form or another.
So they are both – have very serious problems.

2506.09.text:
Read the report; you would have to make the
judgment yourself which is the worst here.

2517.40.text:
AMBASSADOR SAPERSTEIN: Yeah – yes. We have
taken a position in our approach to this that

2526.16.text:
exercise of freedom of religion and belief
allows people to make determinations about

2532.00.text:
what their appropriate re0ligious garb would
be. If women feel they have to have their

2538.68.text:
heads covered, if Sikhs believe that they
have to wear turbans, this is their right.

2548.17.text:
If Jews believe they have to wear yarmulkes,
kippot to cover their head, this should be

2554.24.text:
the determination that each and every person
makes. There may be circumstances in which

2559.59.text:
there are compelling reasons – simply the
need to identify someone or safety reasons

2567.02.text:
– you can’t wear a turban working around
equipment that could catch a turban. If you

2573.61.text:
got to wear a safety helmet, you got to wear
a safety helmet. So accommodations should

2578.60.text:
be made as far as possible. Those exceptions
are really few and far between. We believe

2585.53.text:
that people’s right to live in accordance
with their conscience includes the right to

2590.19.text:
use religious garb and religious dress. We’ve
been critical of other democratic countries

2595.63.text:
as well as nondemocratic countries that have
put such restrictions, and we hope in the

2601.19.text:
future things will ease enough that – and
will be seen in a different perspective that

2606.16.text:
this restriction of religious freedom will
be allowed to fade away.

2610.45.text:
MR TONER: Thank you all, appreciate it. Thank
you, Ambassador.
